comments.author: buzz.support@wordvision.co.uk
comments.text:
As I stated in Bug.Report.txt I have tested Firefox 6 with no plugins active and no extensions> This was achieved by creating a new profile with no extensions and then deleting all the dll files associated with the plugins. I checked that nothing was active in either extensions or plugins and they were both blank. Bookmark dialog does not appear, (but does in Safe Mode). 
The files about.support and about.plugins are from my working Firefox 5.0.1 version. When I install Firefox 6 I point it at the same profile which in my case is located at C:\FirefoxShared6.
I see that about.support contains loads of references to printers that are no longer installed, but were originally on the system from which the profile was originally copied.
Note:
When I install Firefox on a new machine (real or virtual) I copy the profile via one of our servers as this is a lot quicker than downloading and installing loads of extensions.
comments.creator: buzz.support@wordvision.co.uk

Note:

comments.text:
(In reply to SaliesBuzz from comment #6)
> As I stated in Bug.Report.txt I have tested Firefox 6 with no plugins active
> and no extensions> This was achieved by creating a new profile with no
> extensions and then deleting all the dll files associated with the plugins.
> I checked that nothing was active in either extensions or plugins and they
> were both blank. Bookmark dialog does not appear, (but does in Safe Mode). 

Yes, this is what makes no sense.
Let's try another couple things that safe mode does:
1. Disable hardware acceleration from Options / Advanced. Restart (just to be sure) and test
2. in about:config set javascript.options.methodjit.chrome and javascript.options.jitprofiling.chrome to false. Restart and test.
comments.author: mak@mozilla.com
comments.creator: mak@mozilla.com

2. in about:config set javascript.options.methodjit.chrome and javascript.options.jitprofiling.chrome to false. Restart and test.

comments.creator: buzz.support@wordvision.co.uk
comments.text:
Hi Marco,
Yep, it was hardware acceleration. If it is turned off, the dialog re-appears, (without having to do a restart). When Firefox is restarted the dialog still appears. When one turns hardware acceleration back on the dialog still works, but when Firefox restarts (with hardware acceleration on) the dialog disappears. It then re-appears if you turn hardware acceleration off. Hope this makes some sense to you.
I am still baffled as to why it works in Firefox 3,4, and 5 on the same machine with the same profile, extensions and plugins, and only disappears under Firefox 6 (and also 7). There must be some code difference that is not obvious to the user.
Fortunately I have the time and the patience (and the experience) to test these things to death but I can see that the average user would probably move to another browser.
Thanks for your help and insight, I would never have found this!
comments.author: buzz.support@wordvision.co.uk
comments.raw_text:
Hi Marco,
Yep, it was hardware acceleration. If it is turned off, the dialog re-appears, (without having to do a restart). When Firefox is restarted the dialog still appears. When one turns hardware acceleration back on the dialog still works, but when Firefox restarts (with hardware acceleration on) the dialog disappears. It then re-appears if you turn hardware acceleration off. Hope this makes some sense to you.
I am still baffled as to why it works in Firefox 3,4, and 5 on the same machine with the same profile, extensions and plugins, and only disappears under Firefox 6 (and also 7). There must be some code difference that is not obvious to the user.
Fortunately I have the time and the patience (and the experience) to test these things to death but I can see that the average user would probably move to another browser.
Thanks for your help and insight, I would never have found this!
Please, try updating your drivers, if hw accel still misbehave we may want to blacklist that chipset from getting hw acceleration, if it's so much bogus.

comments.text:
(In reply to Marco Bonardo [:mak] from comment #9)
> Please, try updating your drivers, if hw accel still misbehave we may want
> to blacklist that chipset from getting hw acceleration, if it's so much
> bogus.

The system with this problem has an Intel HD Adadpter with an Nvidia Geforce GT525M adapter. I updated all the drivers to the latest available from DELL website last week (17/09/2011). Current Intel HD Driver is v8.15.10.2345. I will check on Intel's site to see if there any further updates and post back again.
comments.raw_text:
(In reply to Marco Bonardo [:mak] from comment #9)
> Please, try updating your drivers, if hw accel still misbehave we may want
> to blacklist that chipset from getting hw acceleration, if it's so much
> bogus.

The system with this problem has an Intel HD Adadpter with an Nvidia Geforce GT525M adapter. I updated all the drivers to the latest available from DELL website last week (17/09/2011). Current Intel HD Driver is v8.15.10.2345. I will check on Intel's site to see if there any further updates and post back again.

It looks like the Intel HD Driver on this computer is a customized version from DELL. The Intel site advises against installing the latest generic driver. I notice in the release notes for the latest Intel Driver (15.22.50.2509 and 15.22.50.64.2509) that amongst the issues fixed is:
WebGL rendering anomaly in Google Chrome* and Mozilla Firefox* browsers resolved. 
Windows 7 Intel HD Graphics 2000 & Intel HD Graphics 3000.
Does this sound like it might be relevant?
When I have finished installing everything on this machine I an going to clone the partition. After that I can try installing the Intel Drivers and see if that cures the problem. This will not be for a couple of days (around 23/09/2011).
I am still bemused why this problem does not appear in Firefox 3,4,or 5.

> NVIDIA GeForce GT 525M driver version is 8.17.12.6721

This rules out a problem with dual-GPU blacklisting, since neither the Intel nor the Nvidia driver version is blacklisted.
